revision_history.draft:
# What the Tin Can Knew

The rust has learned the shape of my joints,
has thumbed the seams loose, each one
letting in a breath of whatever
settled here—a tallow, a tea,

a cursive no one meant to read.
Moss presses its fingers clean across
the name I carried. It rubs slow.
What it discovers: nothing worth

removing. So it writes again,
smaller, softer, part of the green
effacement—I am becoming
wall, become the weather's thin

skin. Drip. Drip. The sound my lungs
would make if I had lungs to spare.

Somewhere a dog lifts its nose.
The world bends down like that.
I feel the pressure of air
thickening against my sides,

and not with expectation—
with the plain fact that something
has softened outside. A cardinal
knocks on what was top. The sound

stays inside me still, the knock,
though I am finished with whatever
message it came to deliver.
The seasons shift their load

across this quiet property.
I do not know what year it is.
Only that moss has made my writing
legible again—and that legibility

is not recovery. Is a kind of
reversal—I read backwards now,
the ink erased to where the tin
knew it before it knew it held

a shape with meaning. I was never
vessel. I was the thing
that happened when the world
was ready to hold something.

Drip. The sound keeps dropping
into whatever filled me.
There is no one to carry it out.
The soil moves through my walls

the way a lung breathes
without being asked—taste of earth,
taste of what I held, becoming
only the fact of this thin

skin, this membrane between
what was and what the spring
has made of it. I do not bloom.
I am the sound left after

bloom. The dog withdraws.
The cardinal flies. And still
the knock reverberates inside me—
a year's worth of silence

between each tap—and I am grateful
for the way forgetting
can be so complete
it leaves a hollow

that even spring
has no use for, and that is
exactly what I always
had to offer.
revision_history.critique:
## Workshop Response

### 1. What's Alive

The central conceit—writing on a tin can as a body, not a vessel—is genuinely compelling. The line "I do not bloom. I am the sound left after / bloom" earns its place: it inverts the expected arc without explaining itself. The dog lifting its nose and the cardinal knocking are two of the poem's sharpest moments—small, physical events that carry enormous meaning through implication.

The rust as a thumb letting breath in is precise and tactile. "Moss presses its fingers clean across" has an unexpected verb choice ("presses," "fingers") that gives moss hands without sentimentalizing it. The line "I do not know what year it is" lands hard because the poem has earned the right to say this plainly.

### 2. What Isn't Working

**Rhyme clutter (throughout).** The rhyme scheme is driving the poem rather than serving it. Lines are being contorted to land rhymes, and words chosen for sound that undermine meaning or imagery. "A cursive no one meant to read" — "read" exists only as a rhyme for "held." Direction: strip all end-rhyme from the draft. Rewrite with only interior consonance and repetition doing work. Let "I do not bloom" stand on its own weight; it doesn't need "bloom" again as rhyme in line 47.

**Abstraction swamping imagery (lines 28–36).** "And still / the knock reverberates inside me— / a year's worth of silence / between each tap—and I am grateful." This reads like prose dressed in lines. Silence is named twice, time is explained, gratitude appears out of nowhere with no earned texture. Direction: replace this passage entirely with one or two physical images that embody what the knock means without narrating it.

**Cliché reemergence (lines 37–40).** "The soil moves through my walls / the way a lung breathes / taste of earth, taste of what I held." The simile collapses into vagueness. "Taste" appears twice in four lines. Direction: choose one sensory verb that doesn't mean anything until placed inside a specific scene.

**Sentimentality (closing).** "And that is / exactly what I always / had to offer." This tells the reader what the poem has already shown, and it does so flatly. The ending earns no final gesture because nothing has been at stake in the last six lines. Direction: cut entirely or replace with a single image that closes without summarizing.

**Line breaks (throughout).** Many lines break on function words ("of," "that," "it") rather than on tension. "I read backwards now, / the ink erased" — "now" as its own line does nothing. Direction: every line break should either complete a thought or

revision_history.draft:
# What the Tin Can Knew

Rust has learned the shape of my joints,
has thumbed each seam loose, and air
finds its crack—a tallow-smell, a tea,
a cursive no one meant to keep.

Moss presses clean across the name I carried.
It rubs slow. Rubbing in, not out—
I am becoming wall, become the thin
skin of weather. Drip. The sound my lungs
would make if I had lungs to spare.

Somewhere a dog lifts its nose.
The world bends down like that.
I feel the air soften outside,
the way it does before rain

crosses what was top. A cardinal
knocks—once, twice, and still
inside me: the sound keeps dropping
into whatever filled me,

and no one stands at my exit now
to carry it out. The soil moves through my walls
the way a lung breathes without being asked—

taste of earth, taste of what I held,
becoming only this thin membrane,
this skin between what was and what

the spring has made of it. I do not bloom.
I am the sound left after—drip.

The dog withdraws. The cardinal flies.
Each tap reverberates inside me: a year's
worth of silence, tight as a nipple
before something asks to be let out.

And I was never vessel anyway.
I was the rust learning my joints,
the moss pressing clean fingers across
what I thought was mine—until

it became mine. The knock again.
The dog has turned its back. The seasons shift.
What year it is, I do not know.
Only that moss has made my writing

almost readable—and almost
isn't. The soft green pushes through the seams,
finds the shape before I did,
before I could hold anything.

Drip. The sound keeps dropping
into whatever filled me.
There's no one left to carry it out.
The soil moves in its slow work—

taste of what I held, becoming only this
thin skin between what was and what
the spring has no use for. Not grief,
exactly—not even the word—

just the knock still inside me,
and gratitude for how forgetting
can make a house so empty
even spring can't decide what to do with it.
The dog keeps walking.
The cardinal drops a feather
on what was top. The sound
keeps dropping, and I keep

being whatever's left after—
the rust learning my joints again,
the moss pressing clean fingers across
what I thought was mine,

until it becomes mine.
revision_history.critique:
## Revision Workshop Response

### 1. What's Alive

The dog lifting its nose and the cardinal knocking are two of the poem's sharpest moments—small, physical events that carry enormous meaning through implication.

"I do not know what year it is" lands hard because the poem has earned the right to say this plainly.

"I was never vessel / I was the thing
that happened when the world
was ready to hold something."

This passage has genuine philosophical stakes. The inversion of vessel-as-container into vessel-as-occurrence is a real idea, and "the world was ready" carries weight without being stated as thesis.

The line "Moss presses its fingers clean across / what I thought was mine—until"

That verb choice ("presses," "fingers") gives moss hands without sentimentalizing it. It's precise and surprising.

### 2. What Isn't Working

**Rhyme clutter (throughout).** The rhyme scheme is driving the poem rather than serving it. Lines are being contorted to land rhymes, and words chosen for sound that undermine meaning or imagery. "A cursive no one meant to read" — "read" exists only as a rhyme for "held." Direction: strip all end-rhyme from the draft. Rewrite with only interior consonance and repetition doing work. Let "I do not bloom" stand on its own weight; it doesn't need "bloom" again as rhyme in line 47.

**Abstraction swamping imagery (lines 28–36).** "And still / the knock reverberates inside me— / a year's worth of silence / between each tap—and I am grateful." This reads like prose dressed in lines. Silence is named twice, time is explained, gratitude appears out of nowhere with no earned texture. Direction: replace this passage entirely with one or two physical images that embody what the knock means without narrating it.

**Cliché reemergence (lines 37–40).** "The soil moves through my walls / the way a lung breathes / taste of earth, taste of what I held." The simile collapses into vagueness. "Taste" appears twice in four lines. Direction: choose one sensory verb that doesn't mean anything until placed inside a specific scene.

**Sentimentality (closing).** "And that is / exactly what I always / had to offer." This tells the reader what the poem has already shown, and it does so flatly. The ending earns no final gesture because nothing has been at stake in the last six lines. Direction: cut entirely or replace with a single image that closes without summarizing.

**Line breaks (throughout).** Many lines break on function words ("of," "that," "it") rather than on tension. "I read backwards now, / the ink erased" — "now" as its own line does nothing. Direction: every line

revision_history.draft:
# What the Tin Can Knew

Rust has learned my hinge, each scored seam
exposed like a tooth in slack jaw,
and air finds its crack—tallow-smell,
a tea-ring, a writing I didn't mean to keep.

Moss presses clean across what I held.
It rubs slow. Not erasing—I'm becoming wall,
becoming the thin skin of rain-slick tin.
Drip. The sound my lungs would make
if I had lungs to spare.

Somewhere a dog lifts its nose.
The world bends down like that.
I feel the softest pressure outside:
the softest pressure before rain

crosses what was top. A cardinal—
once, twice, and still: the knock
keeps dropping into whatever filled me,

and no one stands at my exit now
to carry it out. The soil moves through my walls
the way a lung breathes without being asked—

taste of earth, taste of what I held,
becoming only this thin membrane,
this skin between what was and what

the spring has made of it. I do not bloom.
I am the sound left after—drip.

The dog withdraws. The cardinal flies.
Each tap reverberates inside me: a year's
worth of silence, tight as a nipple
before something asks to be let out.

And I was never vessel anyway.
Rust learning my joints,
moss pressing clean fingers across
what I thought was mine—until

it became mine. The knock again.
The dog has turned its back. The seasons shift.
What year it is, I do not know.
Only that moss has made my writing

almost readable—and almost
isn't. Green pushes through the seams,
finds the shape before I did,

and keeps finding it: a worm
eating backward down a grape stem,
that refusal to stop
before the fruit is gone.

Drip. The sound keeps dropping
into whatever filled me.
There's no one left to carry it out.
The soil moves in its slow work—

taste of what I held, becoming only this
thin skin between what was and what
the spring has no use for. Not grief,
exactly—not even the word—

just the knock still inside me,
and gratitude for how forgetting
can make a house so empty
even spring can't decide what to do with it.
The dog keeps walking.
A feather on what was top.

And I keep being whatever's left after—
the rust learning my joints again,
the moss pressing clean fingers across
what I thought was mine,

until it becomes mine.

revision_history.draft:
Rust has learned my hinge, each scored seam
exposed like a tooth in slack jaw,
and air finds its crack—tallow-smell,
a tea-ring, a writing I didn't mean to keep.

Moss presses clean across what I held.
It rubs slow. Not erasing—I'm becoming wall,
becoming the thin skin of rain-slick tin.
Drip. The sound my lungs would make
if I had lungs to spare.

Somewhere a dog lifts its nose.
The world bends down like that.
I feel the softest pressure outside:
the softest pressure before rain
crosses what was top. A cardinal—

once, twice, and still: the knock
keeps dropping into whatever filled me,

and no one stands at my exit now
to carry it out.

Sore nails on tin again,
each knock a year's worth of silence
tight as a nipple
before something asks to be let out.

Rust learning my joints,
moss pressing clean fingers across
what I thought was mine—until

it becomes mine. The dog has turned its back.
The seasons shift. What year it is, I do not know.
Only that moss has made my writing

almost readable—and almost isn't.
Green pushes through the seams,
finds the shape before I did,

and keeps finding it: a worm
eating backward down a grape stem,
that refusal to stop
before the fruit is gone.

Drip. The sound keeps dropping
into whatever filled me.

The dog keeps walking.
A feather on what was top.

I keep being whatever's left after—
the rust learning my joints again,
the moss pressing clean fingers across
what I thought was mine,

until it becomes mine.
revision_history.critique:
## Revision Workshop Response

### 1. What's Alive

The dog lifting its nose (line 23) and the cardinal knocking (lines 24–25, 28–29, 37–38) — these are two of the poem's sharpest moments: small, physical events that carry enormous meaning through implication. The tin can doesn't "bloom" or "awake." It doesn't change in any stated way; what changes is everything around it.

"I do not know what year it is" lands hard because the poem has earned the right to say this plainly.

"The sound my lungs would make / if I had lungs to spare."

This line works because "lungs" does double duty — breath and weight. It earns its place.

---

### 2. What Isn't Working

**Rhyme clutter (throughout).** The rhyme scheme is driving the poem rather than serving it. Lines are being contorted to land rhymes, and words chosen for sound that undermine meaning or imagery. "A tea-ring, a writing I didn't mean to keep" — "keep" exists only as a rhyme for "seem." Direction: strip all end-rhyme from the draft. Rewrite with only interior consonance and repetition doing work. Let "I do not bloom" stand on its own weight; it doesn't need "bloom" again as rhyme in line 47.

**Abstraction swamping imagery (lines 28–36).** "And still / the knock reverberates inside me— / a year's worth of silence / between each tap—and I am grateful." This reads like prose dressed in lines. Silence is named twice, time is explained, gratitude appears out of nowhere with no earned texture. Direction: replace this passage entirely with one or two physical images that embody what the knock means without narrating it.

**Cliché reemergence (lines 37–40).** "The soil moves through my walls / the way a lung breathes / taste of earth, taste of what I held." The simile collapses into vagueness. "Taste" appears twice in four lines. Direction: choose one sensory verb that doesn't mean anything until placed inside a specific scene.

**Sentimentality (closing).** "And that is / exactly what I always / had to offer." This tells the reader what the poem has already shown, and it does so flatly. The ending earns no final gesture because nothing has been at stake in the last six lines. Direction: cut entirely or replace with a single image that closes without summarizing.

**Line breaks (throughout).** Many lines break on function words ("of," "to," "in") — this creates prose-like flatness where compression is needed. Direction: break lines only to create tension between syntax and breath, not just for rhyme.

final_poem:
Rust has learned the gate's exact geometry,
each scored seam like a tooth in slack jaw,
and air finds its crack—tallow-smell,
a tea-ring, a writing I didn't mean to keep.

Moss presses clean across what I held.
It rubs slow. Not erasing—I'm becoming wall,
becoming the tin so thin it dents with rain.
Drip. The sound my lungs would make
if I had lungs to spare.

Somewhere a dog lifts its nose.
The world bends down like that.
I feel the softest pressure outside:
the softest pressure before rain
crosses what was top—a cardinal—

once, twice, and still: the knock
keeps dropping into whatever filled me,

and no one stands at my exit now
to carry it out.

Sore nails on tin again,
each knock a year's worth of silence
tight as a nipple
before something asks to be let out.

Rust learning my hinge, my latch, my wrist-
joint. Moss pushes clean fingers across
what I thought was mine—until

it becomes mine. The dog has turned its back.
The seasons shift. A nail-head rusted flat,
the kind that holds a curtain or a name,

and moss has eaten through the plastic backing,
is eating through what held it there.

Drip. The sound keeps dropping
into whatever filled me—

a feeder tin beneath the eave,
suspended, its original purpose
already half forgotten in the rust's soft palate.

The dog keeps walking.
A feather on what was top,

and underneath that: the hinge-pinion
caught on nothing—still performing
its small arc, still finding

the slot. Rust learning my joint again,
moss pressing clean across
what I thought was mine until

it becomes mine. The tin gives back
a shape it hadn't held since October,
since someone hung a coat there,

and the moss has already found that coat,
has started eating where the cotton was.
That refusal to stop

before the fabric is gone.

Drip. The sound keeps dropping
into whatever filled me.

The gate swings on its learned hinge now,
its slack jaw barely needing
the dog's lift again as it walks through.
